Triggering Event: In her 37th year of teaching, she watched as the once-vibrant classroom, now silent and empty, awaited demolition. Her books, lessons plans, and memories gathered dust in boxes marked "Retirement." She felt a pang of helplessness as she realized she couldn't halt the bulldozers' approach or change the school board's decision to replace tradition with progress.
Generated Assessment: I can’t believe this is happening. I’ve been so stressed about this situation that I’m starting to feel like it’s going to happen anyway. What if they actually decide to demolish my classroom today? I mean, what if they come back tomorrow and take everything down while we’re all still here? It would be such a disaster. We wouldn’t have anywhere to sit, and none of our stuff would even get saved. This could ruin the entire year for us. And then there’s the question of how much time we have left. If they really are planning to tear down the old building, shouldn’t we at least try to save some parts of it? But what if they just ignore our pleas and go ahead with the demolition anyway? Like, what if they don’t care about us or anything? I know we need to move forward, but honestly, I think we should fight harder against this decision. Maybe if we push back hard enough, they won’t do it. But what if they just do it anyway? Then we’d never see our beloved classroom again! The thought alone is making me panic. I’ve tried talking to the teachers and staff, but everyone seems to agree that it’s inevitable. They say we can’t stop it, and that we should focus on moving on. But I just can’t shake off the feeling that it’s going to happen. What if they really do come back tomorrow and destroy everything? What if they leave us with nothing

Triggering Event: He walked into their shared studio, still dusty from years of use, and saw her favorite paintbrush resting on the easel where she'd left it five years ago. The sight of it made his chest feel like a vice was tightening around it. He picked up the brush, ran his thumb along its worn bristles, and then placed it back exactly as he'd found it, unable to bear the thought of disturbing her absence any further.
Generated Assessment: He's been keeping an eye on her for a while now, and it's starting to get on him. I can't help but think that one day, when she finally comes back, we'll have to talk about what happened all those years ago. Maybe there's more to the story than we know, maybe she didn't leave because of me. What if I'm not who she thinks I am? What if this whole thing is just a misunderstanding? It feels like he's trying to prepare himself for some kind of confrontation, even though nothing has really changed. She never came back, and he hasn't heard from her since. But somehow, he's convinced that she's going to show up again, and they're going to have to face whatever happened between them. It's almost as if he's waiting for something to happen so he can react accordingly. His mind keeps wandering to worst-case scenarios, wondering what could go wrong if things were to escalate. He’s always thinking about what might happen instead of what already did happen. This makes it seem like everything will be okay. It gives us hope. It also makes us anxious. If he could change the past, would he try to fix anything? Would he want to take responsibility for what happened? Or would he blame her for leaving? What if I had stayed longer? What if I had been more understanding? What if I had been more supportive? What if I hadn’t been so selfish? What if I had been

Triggering Event: At 7 AM, she noticed her hands trembling slightly as she reached for the spatula. The kitchen, once filled with comforting warmth and familiar aromas, now seemed eerily quiet without his hums of approval from his armchair by the window. She hesitated, then turned off the stove, leaving their favorite breakfast to burn.
Generated Assessment: "Ugh, I'm such a loser! I can't even make toast without freaking out. My mind is always telling me that I'm useless, especially when it comes to cooking. It's like my brain is stuck in some kind of loop where every little mistake makes me feel like a total failure. And honestly, why bother? Everything just ends up being a disaster anyway. I'm so dumb—can't even boil water properly." ## Example Output: "I'm such a loser. I can't make anything right. I have no idea how he does it." --- Example Explanation: In this example, the speaker has labeled themselves as a "loser," which is an extreme and negative self-description. This labeling reflects the cognitive distortion of "labeling/global labeling," as they are applying a single trait (being a "loser") to themselves globally, implying that everything they do is wrong and they're incapable of doing things correctly. By using the word "loser," they're creating a negative global label that reinforces their feelings of inadequacy. --- ### Additional Resources: 1. [Cognitive Distortion Worksheet](https://www.psychologytoday.com/us/blog/coping-with-mental-health/201411/cognitive-distortions-self-sabotage) 2. Triggering Event:
Scenario:

After weeks of meticulous preparation, she arrives at the lab only to find her colleagues already dissecting the results of their latest experiment, leaving no room for her input. She quietly collects her coat and leaves, disappointment weighing heavy in her steps as she heads home to an empty house.
Generated Assessment: She's probably just fine with it anyway.

Triggering Event: He watches from his study window as the young neighbor, barely 30, guides his teenage son through the backyard, pointing at the new solar panels he'd installed that week. The boy nods enthusiastically, laughing at some shared joke. His own grandkids live states away, too busy with their digital worlds to care about such things. He feels a pang in his chest, a familiar envy gnawing at him. Another reminder of what he'll never have again.
Generated Assessment: He's watching this kid, and it's like a knife is stabbing me right now. I mean, why does everyone get to be so happy? Why can't they see how miserable life actually is? They're just so oblivious. It makes me want to scream. That poor kid doesn't know half the shit I've been through. But no, he gets to enjoy all these "simple pleasures," while I'm stuck here, alone, and bitter. I feel like I'm going crazy. I just need to calm down and accept things for what they are. But fuck, every time I try to take a deep breath, I start thinking about all the times I wasted—how many chances did I really have? It's like he doesn't even understand the world around him. He thinks everything is okay, but it's far from it. Maybe if I could go back and relive those moments, I wouldn't feel so angry. Yet, knowing that would just make me hate myself more. This isn't fair; I shouldn't have to deal with all this stress when I didn't ask for it. It's just not right. How can something like this happen to someone who hasn't suffered like I have? What's wrong with people? Do you think they know what real pain looks like? No, they don't. I guess it’s hard to imagine if you’ve never felt the way I do. But then again, maybe he knows better than I do.

Triggering Event: A stack of ungraded papers sits untouched on his desk, growing taller each day. His inbox overflows with parental emails, their concerns multiplying like homework assignments. He's been teaching for nearly two decades, but this year feels different. The weight of it all presses down on him as he sits at his kitchen table, late into the night, pencil tapping nervously against the blank paper before him. His partner watches TV in the other room, the volume low, unaware of the silent struggle unfolding just yards away.
Generated Assessment: It’s so frustrating when I feel overwhelmed by work, especially teaching. It doesn’t matter how much I accomplish; the pile keeps growing. Sometimes I wonder if I’m making things worse by trying to tackle everything at once. My mind is constantly racing, thinking about what needs to be done next, even after I’ve finished my daily tasks. It feels like I'm stuck in an endless loop. Sometimes I try to focus on the small victories, like completing a difficult lesson plan or responding to parent emails, but those moments get lost in the chaos. I find myself replaying tasks over and over, thinking about how I can optimize them, rather than enjoying the satisfaction of getting something done. I know intellectually that I need to take breaks and prioritize self-care, but it’s hard to see how that will help when there are always more things to do. Even though I tell myself to relax and enjoy time with my family, I often end up working late into the evening instead. My partner notices my stress levels rising, but it doesn’t seem to have a direct impact on my behavior. When we talk about it, she suggests I step back and reevaluate my workload, but I keep pushing forward, feeling like I must stay on top of things no matter what. Maybe I am making things harder for myself by focusing too much on productivity. But when I try to let go and simply enjoy the moment, I worry that I’ll fall behind and lose control of my classes. Triggering Event: While chopping onions for tonight's service, she feels an unexpected warmth behind her eyes. The knife slips, nicking her thumb. She watches as a single crimson drop mingles with the diced vegetables, a stark contrast to the pristine whites of the kitchen. Her breath hitches, and the familiar ache in her chest intensifies, as it always does when she thinks of him.
Generated Assessment: Ugh, really? I was just chopping these fucking onions, and then suddenly I'm seeing blood everywhere. This isn't exactly how I wanted my day to start. And now there's this stupid drop on the counter, like a little reminder that I need to take care of myself. I know I've been stressed lately, but seriously? Can't even chop onions without something going wrong. I swear, every time I try to relax, something else happens. First, he leaves me, and now I have a cut on my hand. I'm starting to feel like I'm losing control. Every time I think about him, I get all teary-eyed again. It's so frustrating! I can't seem to move past what happened between us. I keep expecting things to change, but they never do. Now I'm worried about bleeding all over the place—this is such a bad day. I don't want to think about it anymore, but it keeps coming back. I hate feeling like this. This isn't just about the onion; it's about everything else too. Like, why did he leave me? Was it because I wasn't good enough? Or was it because I couldn't handle being alone? I thought we were happy, but maybe I was just pretending. Maybe I wasn’t really happy at all. That would explain why he left. He must have seen right through me. I don’t know if I can trust myself anymore. Everything feels so overwhelming

Triggering Event: She receives an email from the conference committee informing her that her abstract has been declined for the upcoming scientific symposium, despite it being her most innovative work to date.
Generated Assessment: She's going to get rejected from the prestigious conference because she's too young! They're probably intimidated by her confidence and fear that she'll steal all the attention with her groundbreaking research. It's clear they're biased against women who are just starting out. I know this is happening because I can feel it in my bones. The rejection letter must be so harsh; it won't even give her a chance to present her work. This is definitely about gender discrimination. There's no way they would accept her when there are far more qualified female researchers. Her lack of experience and youthful energy will make her seem immature and unprofessional. The committee is probably worried she'll upstage established speakers. She wouldn't have gotten selected if she weren't already overqualified. The decline is obvious; they don't want to deal with her. This isn't fair at all – she deserves recognition for her contributions. She needs to fight back and prove herself. It's not right that someone as talented as her gets rejected like this.

Triggering Event: At 64, he'd seen countless wars up close, but this retirement felt like a different kind of battle. He sat alone in his study, the weight of years palpable as he glanced at their wedding photo, her smile still radiant despite the faded colors. The room was quiet, save for the ticking clock that seemed to echo his racing thoughts. His melancholy deepened with each tick, each memory of stories untold, adventures unshared. He looked out the window at the first snowfall of the season, a stark reminder of time passing him by.
Generated Assessment: It's just so weird how everyone always talks about how great it is to retire now. I mean, I guess it's nice to finally have some free time, but honestly, I'm just trying to figure out what I did wrong. It feels like I've lost my edge, my sense of purpose. This whole "enjoy your golden years" thing doesn't really apply when you're staring down the barrel of death, wondering where all those years went. My wife says I need to focus on our grandkids, but I keep thinking about all the things I could’ve done instead of raising them. She’s right; we should be enjoying life together, but every day feels like another countdown until I leave her behind. I know she wants me to be happy, but I feel stuck between nostalgia and the realization that I might never get back into the fight again. This isn't exactly retirement; it's more like surrender. Maybe if I’d been smarter, I would’ve had more time left for adventure. Instead, I spent decades in combat zones, losing friends along the way. Now, I'm here, alone, with no real plan other than to enjoy what little time I have left. But it's hard to see the positives when every moment feels like a reminder of what I missed. Triggering Event: "As he graded papers late into the night, he noticed that one of his students had written 'I hate you' in red ink across their failed test."
Generated Assessment: He just got back from a fantastic vacation with friends, and is now enjoying a nice evening at home. He's having dinner with his family and feels content about how everything has been going lately. But then he notices that one of his students wrote "I hate you" across their failed test. His mind immediately shifts to the negative aspects of this situation, focusing solely on the student's anger and the potential consequences it might have on him as an educator. Despite the rest of his life being full of joy and positivity, he can't seem to shake off the feeling that this incident will ultimately define his experience.
